{{Infobox artist |name = Carolina Benedicks-Bruce |image = Carolina Benedicks-Bruce med L'obsède.jpg |image_size = 150 |caption = Carolina Benedicks-Bruce with ''L'obsédé'' |birth_name = Carolina Maria Benedicks |birth_date = {{Birth date|1856|10|28|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Stockholm]], Sweden |death_date = {{Death date and age|1935|2|16|1856|10|28|df=y}} |death_place = [[Visby]], Sweden |nationality = Swedish |known_for = Brucebo |notable_works = ''The wounded bather'' |spouse = [[William Blair Bruce]] |awards = {{awd|''Mention Honorable'', le Salon, Paris|1893}} |website = {{URL|brucebostiftelsen.wix.com}} }}
'''Carolina Maria Benedicks-Bruce''' (28 October 1856 – 16 February 1935) was a Swedish sculptor. After studies at the Academy of Arts in Sweden she went to France, at first to study and later to live and work at the artists' colony in [[Grez-sur-Loing]] where she met her husband [[William Blair Bruce]]. With him she returned to Sweden and together they created the artists estate [[Brucebo]] on [[Gotland]], which was later established as a [[nature reserve]]. She also worked actively with the preservation of heritage buildings, [[Women's suffrage|women's right to vote]] and establishing the [[Swedish Women's Voluntary Defence Service]].
== Early life and education == Benedicks, born on 28 October 1856 in Stockholm, was the daughter of Karolina Charlotta (born Cantzler) and Edward Otto Benedicks,<ref name=Gustaf/> wealthy owner of Gysinge, a part of [[Sandviken]] [[ironworks]].<ref name=gun>{{cite web|last1=Westholm|first1=Gun|title=Carolina Benedicks Bruce|url=http://www.gotland.net/sv/att-gora/carolina-benedicks-bruce|website=www.gotland.net|publisher=Gotlands Media AB|accessdate=12 July 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref> Her brother, Gustaf Benedicks, inherited the iron works and was a member of the Swedish [[Riksdag]].<ref name=Gustaf>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Boëthius|first=B G.|encyclopedia=Svenskt biografiskt lexikon|title=Gustaf Benedicks|url=http://sok.riksarkivet.se/sbl/Presentation.aspx?id=18469|access-date=12 July 2015 |language=Swedish|date=1922|publisher=[[National Archives of Sweden]]|volume=3|pages=159}}</ref> She also had a sister and two half-siblings from her father's second marriage. Her half-brother was physicist [[Carl Benedicks]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lyrholm|first1=Christer|title=Edvard Otto Benedicks|url=http://www.geni.com/people/Edvard-Otto-Benedicks/6000000008996616009|website=www.geni.com|publisher=Geni|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> There were many artists on her mother's side of the family: several of her uncles and her grandmother were painters, among them Johan Oscar Cantzler and Axel Leopold Cantzler. It was through them that Benedicks' artistry was cultivated and developed.<ref name=gun /> She started at the August Malmström art school for women,<ref name=idun /> and from 20{{nbsp}}August 1881 until the spring of 1885,<ref name=kvinnor>{{cite book|last1=Hedberg|first1=Walborg|last2=Arosenius|first2=Louise|title=Svenska kvinnor|date=1914|publisher=Albert Bonniers Förlag|location=Stockholm|page=9|url=https://gupea.ub.gu.se/bitstream/2077/33654/1/gupea_2077_33654_1.pdf|accessdate=5 August 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref> she became the first female student in the sculpture class at the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Arts]].<ref name=riks>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Mörner|first=Stellan G.|encyclopedia=Svenskt biografiskt lexikon|title=Carolina M Benedicks-Bruce|url=http://sok.riksarkivet.se/sbl/Presentation.aspx?id=18472 |access-date=12 July 2015 |language=Swedish|date=1922|publisher=[[National Archives of Sweden]]|volume=3|pages=162}}</ref>
== France == Benedicks met other female artists at the academy including [[Hilma af Klint]] and Gerda Rydberg with whom she travelled to France in 1883. Most of their time was spent in Paris and at the Swedish artist colony in Grez-sur-Loing.<ref name=idun>{{cite journal|last1=Hagéus|first1=Elsa|title=Brucebo och dess härskarinna|trans-title=Brucebo and its matron|journal=Idun|date=27 March 1910|volume=1212|issue=13|pages=154–156|url=http://www.ub.gu.se/fasta/laban/erez/kvinnohistoriska/tidskrifter/idun/1910/pdf/1910_13.pdf|accessdate=12 July 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref> After completing her studies at the academy in Stockholm, she returned to France where she became the student of sculptor [[Alexandre Falguière]].<ref name=riks /> She also returned to Grez-sur-Loing, where many of the more prominent Scandinavian painters at the time would gather during the 1880s. Benedicks met with artists such as [[Carl Larsson]] and his wife [[Karin Bergöö Larsson]], [[Bruno Liljefors]], [[Christian Krohg]] and [[Peder Severin Krøyer]]. In Grez, the Swedish artists created their own, criticized "salon" called ''Le Salon des Opposants''.<ref name=grez>{{cite web|title=Venez à Grez! Venez à Grez!|trans-title=Come to Grez! Come to Grez!|url=http://www.artistes-grezsurloing.fr/|website=www.artistes-grezsurloing.fr|publisher=Associations de Grez-sur-Loing|accessdate=24 August 2015|language=French}}</ref>
Being a single female, with a good artistic education and coming from a wealthy family who encouraged her artistic aspirations, set Benedicks apart from the rest of the artists in the colony. At the time, this was a predominantly male environment, with artists of small means.<ref name=AGH>{{cite web|last1=Lundgren|first1=Jan O.|editor=Bill Manson|title=The Bruce-Benedicks Saga and the Birth of the AGH|url=http://www.artgalleryofhamilton.com/aa_brucebo.php|website=www.artgalleryofhamilton.com|publisher=[[Art Gallery of Hamilton]]|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923174108/http://www.artgalleryofhamilton.com/aa_brucebo.php|archivedate=23 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
== Works == Benedicks was foremost a sculptor, but she also worked with [[etching]]s and [[Watercolor painting|watercolors]]. Her sculptures are heavily influenced by the French style of the 1870s and 1880s, while her paintings and etchings are mostly landscapes and animals. Her works were exhibited for the first time at the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon]] in Paris in 1899, where she participated with her sculpture ''L'obsédé''.<ref name=idun /> She participated in the Paris [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Exposition Universelle]] in 1900, where she was awarded a bronze medal,<ref name=kvinnor /> and later in [[Vienna]].<ref name=riks />
When making [[Bust (sculpture)|busts]], Benedicks worked in [[marble]] and [[bronze]]. ''Michel Angelo'', a bronze bust, depicts [[Michelangelo]] as a thoughtful ordinary man working on something, rather than an exalted genius.<ref name=idun /> She also made busts of [[Gotland Museum#Pehr Arvid Säve|P.A. Säve]] and sculptor [[Emil Wikström]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Carolina Benedicks-Bruce 1856–1935|url=http://www.signaturer.se/Sverige/CarolinaBenedicks.htm|website=www.signaturer.se|publisher=Signaturer.se|accessdate=27 August 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref> Her study of the human anatomy resulted in a humoristic sculpture called ''Séance finie'' or "''The yawning''".<ref name=idun />
Several of Benedicks' sculptures, [[Watercolor painting|aquarelles]] and sketches are still at Brucebo, for example ''L'obsédé'' (''"The Obsessed"''),<ref name=SLU>{{cite web|last1=Svännel|first1=Jessica|title=Vårdprogram för trädgården på Brucebo|trans-title=Care program for the garden at Brucebo|url=http://jessicasvannel.se/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/V%C3%A5rdprogram-f%C3%B6r-Brucebo_12juni14_JessicaSv%C3%A4nnel.pdf|website=www.jessicasvannel.se|publisher=[[Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences]]|accessdate=11 July 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref> ''Baigneur blessé'' (''"The wounded bather"'') that won the ''Mention Honorable'' at the Salon in Paris in 1893.<ref name=stiftelsen>{{cite web|title=Carolina Benedicks-Bruce|url=http://brucebostiftelsen.wix.com/brucebo#!carolina-benedicks-bruce|website=www.brucebostiftelsen.wix.com|publisher=Brucebo Foundation|accessdate=13 July 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref>
== Personal life == [[File:Carolina Benedicks-Bruce and William Blair Bruce.jpg|thumb|upright|Carolina Benedicks-Bruce and William Blair Bruce]] Benedicks met artist [[William Blair Bruce]] in France in the spring of 1885.<ref name="stiftelsen" /> Bruce was still a poor and unknown artist at the time, but a voyage back to Canada in the autumn that year, during which he lost most of his paintings in a shipwreck earned him some notoriety. Benedicks, accompanied by her uncle, made a surprise visit to Canada and Bruce shortly after. Following long discussions, the couple got engaged within a year, against the will of Benedicks' family. They returned to Europe in 1887, where they alternated between Stockholm and Paris. They got married in 1888, and visited Gotland for the first time that year.<ref name=gun /><ref name=AGH /> Theirs was one of many international marriages that came to be as a result of the mixed artist colony in Grez-sur-Loing. Another noted pair was the American painter [[Francis Brooks Chadwick]] and Swedish painter [[Emma Chadwick|Emma Löwstädt-Chadwick]].<ref name=grez /> After the marriage the couple moved to Paris, probably to escape the scrutiny of the Benedicks family. For several years they lived a bohemian life and traveled around Europe to paint and study.<ref name=AGH />
== Brucebo == {{main|Brucebo}} [[File:Carolina Benedicks-Bruce in Brucebo.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Carolina Benedicks-Bruce with dogs and goats in Brucebo]] In 1899, Benedicks-Bruce and her husband decided to settle down on Gotland. They bought properties in Själsö at what was to become Brucebo, north of Visby, and started to rebuild and extend the houses on the estate.<ref name=gun /> Benedicks-Bruce had the money for the project and Bruce was the chief architect.<ref name=blair>{{cite web|title=En William Blair kommer hem|trans-title=A William Blair comes home|url=http://www.lansstyrelsen.se/gotland/Sv/nyheter/2011/Pages/en-william-blair-kommer-hem.aspx?keyword=brucebo+naturreservat|website=www.lansstyrelsen.se|publisher=The County Administrative Boards of [[Gotland County]]|accessdate=27 August 2015|date=8 April 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> They moved to Brucebo in 1900. When Bruce died in 1906, she stayed on in Brucebo and continued with her work. The estate became a social hub for artists, musicians and scientists on Gotland, with Benedicks-Bruce as a generous hostess.<ref name=gun /> She had three workshops at Brucebo and she also kept a number of animals on the estate, such as cows, horses, sheep, goats, dogs, chickens, parrots, monkeys, that she tended to herself.<ref name=idun /> Her interest in [[self-sufficiency]] had started in Grez-sur-Loing, where many of the artists had small gardens where they grew their own vegetables, herbs, fruits and berries. She had great plans for the garden and even brought back seeds from France to plant, as well as hiring a gardener. However, the extension of buildings and other architectural improvements came to a halt with Bruce's death.<ref name=SLU />
She lived at Brucebo until her death on 16 February 1935.<ref name="stiftelsen" /> She had no children to inherit from her,<ref name=blair /> and in her will she stated that Brucebo should remain a place where young artists could stay and develop their artistry.<ref name=SLU /> In 1972, this was realized with the creation of the [[Brucebo#Brucebo Foundation|Brucebo Fine Art Scholarship Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Brucebo and W.B. Bruce Fine Art Scholarships for Canadian Artists|url=http://www.swedenabroad.com/en-GB/Embassies/Ottawa/Study-in-Sweden/Scholarships/Brucebo-and-WB-Bruce-Fine-Art-Scholarships-2012-2013/|website=www.swedenabroad.com|publisher=[[List of diplomatic missions in Ottawa|Embassy of Sweden, Ottawa]]|accessdate=14 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709022007/http://www.swedenabroad.com/en-GB/Embassies/Ottawa/Study-in-Sweden/Scholarships/Brucebo-and-WB-Bruce-Fine-Art-Scholarships-2012-2013/#|archive-date=2015-07-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
== Social commitments == Benedicks-Bruce was a unique and strong woman for her time, engaged in political and social issues and has been called a Swedish "[[Emmeline Pankhurst|Mrs. Pankhurst]]".<ref name=idun /> Among the things she fought for was the women's right to vote. When the [[Sixth Conference of the International Woman Suffrage Alliance]] was held in Stockholm in 1911, she invited the delegates to Gotland. About 40 of them from Germany, England, Austria and Hungary accepted and came to [[Visby]] on 21{{nbsp}}June. She also worked with Gotlandic questions and was one of the most ardent advocates for the preservation of the ''Burmeisterska huset'', a 17th-century house in Visby. She was also a key figure in the establishment of the Swedish Women's Voluntary Defence Service on Gotland.<ref name=gun />
In 1911, she was a member of the [[Väskinde]] school council and a year later, part of the Väskinde Fruit Growers Association. In 1913, she became a member of the Väskinde Municipality Counsil.<ref name=kvinnor /> Benedicks-Bruce also made generous donations to the conservation of heritage buildings, childcare and [[orphanage]]s.<ref name=blair />
== Gallery == <gallery perrow="5" widths="180" heights="140"> File:Gäsparen av Carolina Benedicks-Bruce.jpg|''The yawning'' (''Séance finie'') by Benedicks-Bruce File:Brucebo atelje söder.jpg|The south part of the studio in Brucebo, Benedicks-Bruce's ''L'obsède'' (left, back), ''Michel Angelo'' and bust of her husband (right, front) File:Brucebo atelje.jpg|The studio in Brucebo, one of Benedicks-Bruce's sculptures and her husband's full figure portrait of her File:Brucebo salong.jpg|Brucebo artist's home, room with Bruce's portrait of Benedicks-Bruce </gallery>

The '''Contemporary Arts Society''' was founded by [[John Goodwin Lyman|John Lyman]] in 1939 to promote [[modern art]] in [[Montreal]], at a time when [[Canada]] was dominated by [[academic art]].<ref name="CanadianEncyclopedia">{{cite web|title=Contemporary Arts Society|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/contemporary-arts-society/|website=The Canadian Encyclopedia|accessdate=25 November 2017}}</ref>
Lyman was the Society's first president. The additional officers were vice-president [[Paul-Émile Borduas]], secretary [[Fritz Brandtner]], and treasurer [[Philip Surrey]].<ref name="CanadianPainting30s">{{cite web|title=Canadian Painting in the 30s: part 7. The Eastern Group and the Contemporary Arts Society|url=http://cybermuse.gallery.ca/cybermuse/enthusiast/thirties/html_chapters/catalogue_7_en.html|website=National Gallery of Canada|accessdate=25 November 2017}}</ref>
==Early membership== Early member included Alexandre Bercovitch, Paul-Émile Borduas, [[Simone Mary Bouchard]], Stanley Cosgrove, [[Louise Landry Gadbois]], [[Eric Goldberg (artist)|Eric Goldberg]], [[Jack Humphrey]], [[John Goodwin Lyman]], [[Louis Muhlstock]], [[Alfred Pellan]] [[Goodridge Roberts]], [[Jori Smith]], and Philip Surrey.<ref name="Carney">{{cite book|last1=Carney|first1=Lora Senechal|title=Canadian Painters in a Modern World, 1925–1955: Writings and Reconsiderations|date=2017|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=0773551921|pages=146|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y-EyDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA173&lpg=PA173&dq=Louise+Gadbois&source=bl&ots=jM5dWEAZLq&sig=z8CBqFxHKkg45G6LrbTJrUQm-_s&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjH1rXsxtrXAhXk6IMKHeinCbs4ChDoAQhXMAk#v=onepage&q=Louise%20Gadbois&f=false|accessdate=25 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="CanadianPainting30s"/>

Despite being an imported tradition, [[Comics|comic art]] had a significant impact on [[Myanmar|Burmese]] visual culture. Comic art is a form of visual expression defined by sequences of juxtaposed panels containing stylised images with bold outlines which incorporate text or symbols as an integral part of the narrative. Introduced by members of the British colonial elite, who were also amateur artists, cartooning and comic art was embraced by Burmese artists as a new mode of visual and critical expression. First appearing in the early 1910s, within two decades comics and cartoons emerged as a significant vehicle by which political and social criticism could be made within Burma's restricted public arena.<ref>Aung Soe Min, “Comic Culture in Myanmar: When Lines Shine a Light in the Darkness,” Goethe Institut, accessed April 30, 2016, https://www.goethe.de/ins/mm/en/kul/mag/20697882.html.</ref> As the number of print publications in Burma grew, from 22 in 1911 to 103 in 1921 and finally to over 200 by the close of the 1930s, comics became a substantial avenue for entertainment, art and discourse.<ref>John A Lent, Asian Comics (Jackson: University Press of Mississippi, 2015), 177.</ref>
== Origins and influences == The first cartoon published in Burma appeared in the [[The Rangoon Times|''Rangoon Times'']] in 1912.<ref>Ibid, 175.</ref> The cartoon was created by Martin Jones, the British commissioner of Burma's railways. It depicted a young [[Bamar people|Burmese]] woman who attended a Western party and was subsequently humiliated.<ref>Aung Zaw, “Pioneers of Burmese Cartooning,” ''Irrawaddy'' 11, no. 7 (2003), accessed April 30, 2016, http://www2.irrawaddy.com/article.php?art_id=3069&page=1.</ref> Jones published the derogatory illustration under the pseudonym Myauk, the derivation of the Burmese term ''myauk phyu'' meaning ‘white monkey’.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 175.</ref> A term the Burmese used to refer to the British colonial forces who [[British rule in Burma|occupied Burma]] from 1824 to 1948.<ref>Virginia Thompson, “Burma,” in ''South East Asia: Colonial History - Vol IV'', ed. Paul H Kratoska (London: Routledge, 2001), 81.</ref>
Jones along with fellow amateur colonial painters physics professor Kenneth Ward and principal of St. Mathews High School in [[Mawlamyaing|Moulmien]] E G N Kinch founded the [[Burma Art Club]] in 1913.<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; Andrew Ranard, ''Burmese Painting: A Linear and Lateral History'' (Chiang Mai: Silkworm Publications, 2009), 91; cf Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 175, Lent suggests that the Burma Art Club was established in 1917. This may be a confusion surrounding the date of the Club’s founding which occurred in 1913 and its formalisation which followed in 1918.</ref> Their efforts were assisted by Commissioner Hla Aung and his partner Mya May, along with several young Burmese artists including Ba Zaw, [[Ba Nyan]], Tha Dun, Tun Hla, and [[Ba Kyi]].<ref>Ranard, ''Burmese Painting'', 91-2; Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 175.</ref> Located on the grounds of the Rangoon Government High School,<ref>Irene Moilanen and Sergeĭ Sergeevich Ozhegov, ''Mirrored in Wood: Burmese Art and Architecture'' (Bangkok: White Lotus Press, 1999), 162.</ref> the Burma Art Club was a colonial art institution with the objective of promoting Western-style painting and drawing, including cartooning, to select Burmese students.<ref>Ranard, ''Burmese Painting'', 92-3.</ref> It has been suggested by art historian Andrew Ranard that: {{Quote|text=Burmese students who studied cartoon art at the Burma Art Club felt some affinity for this new genre because it possessed elements of exaggeration with which they were already familiar in Traditional painting… Pagan painting and the mural painting of Burma from the 17th to 19th centuries had a strong taste for caricature in its depictions of fairy-tale figures, demons, and beasts…<ref>Ibid, 92.</ref>|sign=|source=}} Among the first initiates to receive training from the establishment were the now notable Burmese cartoonists [[Shwe Yoe|Ba Gale]], also known as Shwe Talay or Shwe Yoe, and [[Ba Gyan]].<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 175.</ref> It is considered that the beginning of Burma's comic art movement was defined by these individuals.<ref>John A Lent, “Cartooning in Southeast Asia,” in ''Encyclopedia of Humour Studies'', ed. Salvatore Attardo (Thousand Oaks: Sage Publications, 2014), 725.</ref>
== Ba Gale == {{Main|Shwe Yoe}}Ba Gale (1893-1945) was a formative figure in Burma's burgeoning comic art scene. His career began in 1915, after publishing a cartoon in the ''Rangoon College Annual Magazine'' at the age of 22.<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; Myo Thant, “Social Critics, Satirists and Humourists” (paper presented at the National Workshop on Copyright: Myanmar’s Gateway to IP, Yangon, September 7, 2005), accessed April 30, 2016, http://www.accu.or.jp/appreb/02/02-02/02-02country/previous/prev_mm.html.</ref> Crucially, he was the first artist to draw and publish a cartoon in the Burmese language, which appeared in ''Thuriya'', a publication run by young nationalists, in March 1917.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 175.</ref> Earning 10-15 kyat per cartoon (approximately AU $0.17) Ba Gale sought to make cartooning his career.<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”.</ref> His works subsequently appeared in the [[The Rangoon Times|''Rangoon Times'']] and as part of the editorial pages in other smaller local newspapers.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
[[File:Ba Gale Shwedagon Comic.png|thumb|Ba Gale, Shwedagon shoe controversy comic, c. 1917]]
Ba Gale's style drew heavily from the European tradition of [[caricature]]. During his time at the Burma Art Club, he was introduced to and subscribed to the British comic publication ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'', known for its political and social satire.<ref>Ranard, ''Burmese Painting'', 92.</ref> Despite being acknowledged as an adept artist and an astute pictorial commentator, the Burmese public initially found it difficult to understand and interpret Ba Gale's exaggerated and stylised drawing style.<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 175; This would seem to contradict Ranard’s assertion that elements of caricature could be identified in early Burmese temple paintings making the style familiar. Perhaps the similarities were clearer for individuals with an artist training and background, such as the students of the Burma Art Club as opposed to the general Burmese population.</ref> Writer and social historian Aung Zaw notes that: {{Quote|text=To gain popular acceptance, Ba Gale’s cartoons were often accompanied by long captions or described poetically by editors. During British rule, captions often appeared in English. Respected Burmese literary figure Sayagyi Thakin Kodaw Hmaing edited The Sun and wrote many captions for Ba Gale, contributing to the public’s appreciation of the cartoonist…<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; see also Aung Soe Min, “Comic Culture in Myanmar”.</ref>|sign=|source=}}
Even in its earliest stages, Burmese comic art was political. Despite being a regular fixture within the English-language periodicals that circulated throughout Burma, Ba Gale's works often parodied the British administration.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 176; Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; Aung Soe Min, “Comic Culture in Myanmar”.</ref> However, he did not limit his critique to the colonialists. He also used comic art to critic prominent social issues such as opportunistic politicians and what he perceived as sycophantic behaviour towards the British.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 176; Aung Soe Min, “Comic Culture in Myanmar”.</ref> Considered one of Ba Gale's most famous cartoons is his portrayal of the 1917 resolution to forbid colonial forces from wearing shoes within the [[Shwedagon Pagoda]]; an act which was forbidden by Burmese religious custom.<ref>Elizabeth Moore, Hansjörg Mayer and U Win Pe, ''Shwedagon: Golden Pagoda of Myanmar'' (Bangkok: River Books, 1999), 150.</ref> Ba Gale illustrated the portly colonialists, identified by their opulent Western dress, riding on the back of Burmese people like horses so that they did not have to obey the custom of removing their shoes within the Shwedagon. Ba Gale does not just lampoon the British and their disrespectful behaviour he also questions the attitudes of those Burmese people who assist them.<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; Aung Soe Min, “Comic Culture in Myanmar”; Donald Seekins, ''Historical Dictionary of Burma (Myanmar)'' (Maryland: Scarecrow Press Inc, 2006), 136.</ref> Ba Gale, however, did not escape criticism entirely. A cartoon which depicted [[Saya San|the leader]] of a 1930 peasant uprising as a hero earned him substantial condemnation from British officials, though he was never jailed.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 176; Aung Zaw notes the leniency which cartoonists enjoyed under British rule, particularly when compared with the censorship imposed by the subsequent military juntas that ruled Burma from 1962 until 2010. He considers that this relative freedom was an important aspect in the initial development of a Burmese comic art.</ref> Towards the mid-1920s Ba Gale transitioned into filmmaking and acting where he gained significant popularity.
== Ba Gyan == {{Main|Ba Gyan}} The political inclination first seen in Ba Gale's work was furthered by his contemporary Ba Gyan (1902-1953) who rose to prominence in the 1930s with his bold cartoons and nationalist agenda.<ref>Bertil Littner, “Avoiding the Draft,” ''Far Eastern Economic Review'' 148, vol. 3 (1991): 32.</ref> Ba Gyan, like Ba Gale, also trained at the Burma Art Club where he was singled-out by founder Martin Jones for his ‘talent, humour and desire to entertain.’<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”; see also Ranard, ''Burmese Painting'', 92.</ref> Ba Gyan's practice traversed a number of fields. In addition to working as an editorial cartoonist, he also illustrated children's magazines, worked as a commercial photographer, novelist and animator.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 176.</ref> Ba Gyan was instrumental in establishing the Burmese animation industry. In 1934 and 1935 he produced Burma's first animated films, ''Kye Taungwa'' and ''Athuya'' respectively.<ref>Ibid, 177.</ref> Previously, Burmese comic art had been restricted to single cartons or limited panel short stories, however, in 1937 Ba Gyan created Burma's first comic book, ''Ko Pyoo and Ma Pyone''.<ref>Myo Thant, “Social Critics”.</ref> At this stage Ba Gyan also began to work with recurring characters whose antics would be developed and explored across the political and humour panels of several major publications.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 177.</ref>
[[File:Ba Gyan Comic.jpg|thumb|Ba Gyan, ''[[Tatmadaw]]'' (Armed Forces) political comic, first published 1952. Text running upper centre to centre right translates to, '1952 - The plan to not split the people and the Armed Forces'.]]
After Burma gained its independence in 1948, Ba Gyan's comic production became explicitly political and highly critical.<ref>Seekins, ''Historical Dictionary of Burma'', 136.</ref> Of particular significance was a cartoon which appeared in a local newspaper on January 4, 1948. The comic depicted British General Sir [[Hubert Rance]] departing Burma, waving goodbye to a local family as he tells them ‘Take care of your children.’<ref>Aung Soe Min, “Comic Culture in Myanmar”.</ref> Behind the amicable scene are three children each symbolising a damage caused by the Second World War: debt, destruction and economic crisis.<ref>Ibid.</ref> Ba Gyan's use of metaphor as a communicative device shows a growing sophistication and maturing in Burma's comic art movement. Gallerist and collector [[Aung Soe Min]] claims that the cartoon's popularity stemmed from its ability to concisely express Burma's situation at the time.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
Post-independence Ba Gyan took a firmly partisan stance satirising both sides of Burma's new political regime; lampooning the [[Prime Minister of Myanmar|Prime Minister]] [[U Nu]] and the opposing communist leader [[Thakin Than Tun]].<ref>Aung Zaw, “Burmese Cartooning”.</ref> Aung Zaw notes that Ba Gyan's influence was respected and recognised by these figures. By the early 1950s Burma was embroiled in political turmoil and on the cusp of a civil war, in a bid to quell a social uprising Prime Minister U Nu sought a meeting with Ba Gyan asking him to only exhibit cartoons which exhibited peace and unity.<ref>Ibid.</ref> Famously, he refused to compromise informing U Nu that he was too busy to attend the meeting.<ref>Ibid.</ref> Ba Gyan, and other early cartoonists such as Hein Sung, viewed their role as ‘public watchdog’s’ who were responsible for keeping the Burma's independent power structures in check.<ref>Littner, “Avoiding the Draft,” 32.</ref>
== Post-independence Onwards == The proceeding period of development in Burma's comic art which spanned from the early 1950s until the [[1962 Burmese coup d'état|military takeover of 1962]] was an era of growth and experimentation in which younger artists expanded on the visual tradition established by Ba Gale and Ba Gyan.<ref>Myo Thant, “Social Critics”.</ref> Without the competition of television, periodicals inundated with comics became one of the major sources of entertainment particularly for the younger generation.<ref>Lent, ''Asian Comics'', 177.</ref> However, following the 1962 coup by the socialist, military leader [[Ne Win]], Burma's comic art with its fundamental political basis languished under the strictures of the junta.<ref>Seekins, ''Historical Dictionary of Burma'', 136.</ref> Comic art stagnated until the 1970s when developments in the book publishing industry helped to revive the practice.<ref>Myo Thant, “Social Critics”; Tin Maung Muang Than, “The Media in Myanmar,” in ''Media Fortunes, Changing Times: ASEAN States in Transition'', ed. Russell Hiang-Khng Heng (Pasir Panjang: Institute of Southeast Asian Studies, 2002), 145.</ref>

[[File:Tomba dei Rilievi (Banditaccia).jpg|thumb|Tomb of the Reliefs at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis]] [[File:Porta-marzia-bn.jpg|thumb|The 2nd-century Porta Marzia at [[Perugia]], its upper part built into a later wall]] [[File:Temple étrusque 2.jpg|thumb|Detail of the Villa Giulia temple reconstruction]]
'''Etruscan architecture''' was created between about 700 BC and 200 BC, when the expanding civilization of [[ancient Rome]] finally absorbed [[Etruscan civilization]]. The Etruscans were considerable builders in stone, wood and other materials of temples, houses, tombs and city walls, as well as bridges and roads. The only structures remaining in quantity in anything like their original condition are tombs and walls, but through archaeology and other sources we have a good deal of information on what once existed.
From about 630 BC, Etruscan architecture was heavily influenced by [[Greek architecture]], which was itself developing through the same period.<ref>Boethius, 34; see Izzet, 20–21 for a discussion of Etruscan cultural importing in general</ref> In turn it influenced [[Roman architecture]], which in its early centuries can be considered as just a regional variation of Etruscan architecture. But increasingly, from about 200 BC, the Romans looked directly to Greece for their styling, while sometimes retaining Etruscan shapes and purposes in their buildings.<ref>Boardman, 220, 255</ref>
The main monumental forms of Etruscan architecture, listed in decreasing order of the surviving remains, were: the houses of the wealthy elite, the mysterious "monumental complexes", temples, city walls, and rock-cut tombs. Apart from the podia of temples and some house foundations, only the walls and rock-cut tombs were mainly in stone, and have therefore often largely survived.<ref>Christofani</ref>
==Temples== The early Etruscans seem to have worshipped in open air enclosures, marked off but not built over; sacrifices continued to be performed outside rather than inside temples in traditional [[Roman religion]] until its end. It was only around 600 BC, at the height of their civilization, that they began to create monumental temples, undoubtedly influenced by the Greeks<ref>Taylor</ref> That these buildings developed essentially from the largest types of Etruscan house has been both asserted and challenged.<ref>Izzet, 19–21</ref>
Usually, only the [[podium]] or base platform used stone, with the upper parts of wood and mud-brick, greatly reducing what survives for archaeologists.<ref>Boethius, 48; Christofani</ref> However, there is evidence for the portico columns sometimes using stone, as at [[Veii]].<ref>Banti, 31–32; Boethius, 59</ref> This has left much about Etruscan temples uncertain. The only written account of significance on their architecture is by [[Vitruvius]] (died after 15 BC), writing some two centuries after the Etruscan civilization was absorbed by Rome. He describes how to plan a "Tuscan temple" that appears to be a Roman "Etruscan-style" ("tuscanicae dispositiones") temple of a type perhaps still sometimes built in his own day, rather than a really historically-minded attempt to describe original Etruscan buildings, though he may well have seen examples of these.<ref>Christofani; Boethius, 33–34</ref>
Many aspects of his description fit what archaeologists can demonstrate, but others do not. It is in any case clear that Etruscan temples could take a number of forms, and also varied over the 400-year period during which they were being made.<ref>Banti, 31–32</ref> Nonetheless Vitruvius remains the inevitable starting point for a description, and a contrast of Etruscan temples with their [[Greek temple|Greek]] and [[Roman temple|Roman]] equivalents. There are also a few model temples in pottery, and depictions on tombs or vases. Remains of the architectural terracotta elements sometimes survive in considerable quantities, and museums, mostly in Italy, have good collections of attractively shaped and painted [[antefix]]es in particular.<ref>Banti, 32</ref>
Vitruvius specifies three doors and three [[cella]]e, one for each of the main Etruscan deities, but archaeological remains do not suggest this was normal, though it is found.<ref>Christofani</ref> Roman sources were in the habit of ascribing to the Etruscans a taste for triads in things such as city planning (with three gates to cities, for example), in ways that do not seem to reflect reality.<ref>Boethius, 35</ref> The orientation of the temple is not consistent, and may have been determined by a priest watching the flight of birds at the time of foundation.<ref>Christofani</ref> [[File:Museo archeologico di Firenze, frontone di Talamone 1.JPG|thumb|left|380px|Late terracotta pediment (part-reconstructed) from [[Talamone]]]] The exteriors of both Greek and Roman temples were originally highly decorated and colourful, especially in the [[entablature]] and roofs, and this was if anything even more true of Etruscan temples. When wood was used for columns, the bases and capitals were often encased in painted terracotta.<ref>Boethius, 59</ref> All the edges of the roof were decorated, mostly in brightly painted terracotta, and there seem often to have been a row of sculptures along the central ridge of the roof, going beyond the [[acroterion]] group above a [[pediment]] in Greek and Roman temples. The [[Apollo of Veii]] was part of an acroterion group.<ref>Boethius, 59–63; Boardman, 255</ref> Substantial but broken remains of late sculptured pediment groups survive in museums, in fact rather more than from Greek or Roman temples, partly because the terracotta was not capable of "recycling" as [[marble]] was. The groups from [[Luna (Etruria)|Luni]] and [[Talamone]] (both now in [[Florence]]) are among the most impressive.<ref>Christofani; Banti, 31–32</ref>
Features shared by typical Etruscan and Roman temples, and contrasting with Greek ones, begin with a strongly frontal approach, with great emphasis on the front facade, less on the sides, and very little on the back. The podia are also usually higher, and can only be entered at a section of the front, just presenting a blank platform wall elsewhere. There may only be columns at the front portico.<ref>Christofani</ref> In Etruscan temples, more than Roman ones, the portico is deep, often representing, as Vitruvius recommends, half of the area under the roof, with multiple rows of columns.<ref>Christofani</ref>
At least in later temples, versions of Greek [[Aeolic order|Aeolic]], [[Ionic order|Ionic]] and [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] capitals are found, as well as the main [[Tuscan order]], a simpler version of the [[Doric order|Doric]], but the attention to the full Greek detailing in the entablature that the Romans pursued seems to have been lacking. Fluted Tuscan/Doric columns can also be found, against Greek and later Roman conventions.<ref>Boethius, 49–54</ref>
Etruscan architecture shared with [[Ancient Egyptian architecture]] the use of large [[cavetto]] mouldings as a [[cornice]], though not on the same massive scale. The cavetto took the place of the Greek [[cymatium]] in many temples, often painted with vertical "tongue" patterns (as in the reconstructed Etruscan temple at [[Villa Giulia]], illustrated above), and combined with the distinctive "Etruscan round moulding", often painted with scales.<ref>Winter, 61-67; [[:File:Villa Giulia ricostruzione del tempio etrusco 01.JPG|Another view of the reconstructed Etruscan temple]] at [[Villa Giulia]]</ref>
===Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus=== [[File:TempleofCapitoliumRome.jpg|thumb|Speculative model of the first [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus]] in Rome]] The first building of the [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus]] on the [[Capitoline Hill]] was the oldest large temple in Rome, dedicated to the [[Capitoline Triad]] consisting of Jupiter and his companion deities, [[Juno (mythology)|Juno]] and [[Minerva]], and had a cathedral-like position in the official religion of Rome. Its first version was traditionally dedicated in 509 BC,<ref>[[Ab urbe condita (book)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 2.8</ref> but in 83 BC it was destroyed by fire, and the rebuilt Greek-style temple completed in 69 BC (there were to be two more fires and new buildings). For the first temple Etruscan specialists were brought in for various aspects of the building, including making and painting the extensive terracotta elements of the [[entablature]] or upper parts, such as [[antefix]]es.<ref>Stamper, 12–13</ref> But for the second building they were summoned from Greece.
The first version is the largest Etruscan temple recorded,<ref>Christofani; Boethius, 47</ref> and much larger than other Roman temples for centuries after. However, its size remains heavily disputed by specialists; based on an ancient visitor it has been claimed to have been almost {{convert|60|×|60|m|abbr=on}}, not far short of the largest Greek temples.<ref>Boethius, 47–48</ref> Whatever its size, its influence on other early Roman temples was significant and long-lasting.<ref>Stamper, 33 and all Chapters 1 and 2. Stamper is a leading protagonist of a smaller size, rejecting the larger size proposed by the late [[Einar Gjerstad]].</ref> Reconstructions usually show very wide eaves, and a wide colonnade stretching down the sides, though not round the back wall as it would have done in a Greek temple.<ref>Christofani</ref> A crude image on a coin of 78 BC shows only four columns, and a very busy roofline.<ref>[[:File:Tempel Jupiter Optimus.JPG|Denarius of 78 BC]]</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Etruskisk tempel.svg|Temple plan, following Vitruvius and the [[Portonaccio]] Minerva temple, with 3 doors File:Orvieto Tempio Etrusco Del Belvedere.JPG|Temple podium at [[Orvieto]]; above this level stone was probably not used File:Tempio di veio.JPG|Temple of Apollo, [[Portonaccio (Veio)|Veii]], with partial modern visualization File:St. Paul's Church, Covent Garden, London.jpg|[[St Paul's, Covent Garden]], London, 1630s, largely follows [[Vitruvius]]'s directions for a "Tuscan temple", but lacks external decoration and colour. File:Gorgoneion dal tempio di belvedere, orvieto, fine V sec. ac..JPG|[[Gorgon]] antefix, [[Orvieto]], end 5th century. Heads of both Silenus and gorgons were common subjects for antefixes. File:Antefissa a testa di sileno, 500-490 ac ca., da lanuvio (terme di diocleziano).JPG|Antefix with [[Silenus]], 500-490 BC File:MMA etruscan head0.jpg|Antefix File:Frontone A del grande tempio di luni con concilio degli dei, 175-150 ac. ca. 01.JPG|Remains of terracotta pediment group from [[Luna (Etruria)|Luna]] (paler areas reconstructed). </gallery>
==Monumental complexes== [[File:Terracotta architectural details Acquarossa.jpg|thumb|Frieze from [[Acquarossa, Italy|Acquarossa]] (Zone F)]] "Monumental complex" or building is a term used for a few large sets of buildings relatively recently uncovered by archaeology, the term reflecting a lack of certainty over their function. The two leading examples are "[[Poggio Civitate#The large Archaic building|the Archaic building]]" at [[Poggio Civitate]] and another at [[Acquarossa, Italy|Acquarossa]] (Zone F); both are 6th-century or earlier. Both have sets of buildings round a courtyard, which use stone, at least in the foundations, roof tiles, and elaborate decorations in architectural terracotta. Their size is exceptional for their early date. One obvious possible function is as palatial dwellings; another is as civic buildings, acting as places for assembly, and commemoration of aspects of the community. Only the stone foundations and ceramic fragments remain for excavations to discover.<ref>Meyers, 2–6</ref>
==Houses== It seems clear from the richer tombs that the Etruscan elite lived in fairly spacious comfort, but there is little evidence as to what their homes looked like, although some furniture is shown in tomb frescos. The rock-cut tomb chambers often form suites of "rooms", some quite large, which presumably resemble in part the [[atrium (architecture)|atrium]] homes of the better-off Etruscans.<ref>Boethius, 75–89; Banti, 27–28; Christofani</ref> Unlike several of the necropoli, Etruscan cities have generally been built over from the Romans onwards, and houses have left little trace. Where remains survive, there are tightly-packed tufa bases, with perhaps mud-brick above, but in some places the lower parts of tufa walls survive even in small houses. One complete set of foundations shows a house 7.9m by 3.9m (25 x 13 feet).<ref>Boethius, 75–77</ref> At large farms, mines, quarries and perhaps other sites employing many people (many or mostly slaves), workers lived in dormitories. [[File:Maquettes of houses from c 1000 BC.jpg|thumb|left|Selection of hut urns]]
A form of models of houses in pottery, and sometimes bronze, called "hut urns" gives us some indications. These were apparently used to hold cremated ashes, and are found in the preceding [[Villanovan culture]] and early Etruscan burials, especially in northern areas.<ref>Banti, 25; Boethius, 26–27</ref> The hut urns show a conventional model with a single interior space. They are usually round or slightly oval, often with prominent wooden beams laid in two rows on the sloping roof, which cross at the central ridge and project some way in "V"s into the air; these projections seem to have been sometimes carved or otherwise decorated. The urns always have a large square-ish door for access, sometimes two, and the outline of windows in the walls may be indicated by ridges or marks in the clay. There is very often a window and exit for smoke, above the door in the roof, and at the opposite end.<ref>Boethius, 26–27</ref>
Such houses were made of earth and organic materials, using mud brick and [[daub and wattle]].<ref>Banti, 25</ref> Stone [[hearth]]s and perhaps stone rings at the base are found. Even the well-off seem rarely to have lived in stone houses, and rock-cut tomb chambers often represent wooden ceilings in stone. The "Tomb of the Reliefs" at Banditaccia suggests that possessions such as tools and weapons were often hung from the walls for storage.<ref>Christofani</ref>
On the [[Palatine Hill]] in Rome, the [[Casa Romuli]] ("House of [[Romulus]]") was long preserved, and when necessary rebuilt as before. It was a hut made of wood posts and roof beams, [[wattle and daub]] walls and a [[thatch]]ed roof,<ref>Richardson, 74</ref> and possibly typical of ordinary Etruscan housing outside crowded city centres.<ref>Christofani</ref> The site cannot be identified with certainty, but at one candidate location circle of six [[post-hole]]s plus a central one have been found, cut into the tufa bedrock, with an ovoid 4.9m x 3.6m perimeter.
==Tombs and tumuli== [[File:Banditaccia Tomba Dei Capitelli.jpg|thumb|[[Banditaccia]] necropolis, Tomb of the Capitelli]] Rich Etruscans left elaborate tombs, mostly gathered in large [[necropoli]] some way outside their cities. These were generously filled with [[grave goods]],<ref>Banti, 20–21, 26, 28</ref> especially ceramics, which give us most of our understanding of Etruscan culture.<ref>Izzet, 16</ref> Typically, in the tufa regions of southern Etruria, the burial chamber was cut from solid rock below ground, which is relatively easy with this rock, but there was a structure above, often rather large. In other regions they are normally built up above ground.<ref>Banti, 21</ref> They were reused for further burials in the same family over several generations, and would often have become very crowded with sarchophagi and grave-goods, though the known survivals have now been emptied, either by looters or archaeologists.
Some tombs are stone buildings, often in rows, rather like small houses. Others are round [[tumuli]] with stone retaining walls, with steps down to rock-cut chambers below. Both types are found closely packed together in necropoli like [[Banditaccia]] and [[Monterozzi necropolis|Monterozzi]], the latter containing some 6,000 burials. Several different types of tombs have been identified, reflecting a development through time as well as differences in income. Some types clearly replicate aspects of the richer houses, with a number of connected chambers, columns with capitals, and rock-cut ceilings given beams.<ref>Christofani; Izzet, 16–17, cautions against transferring such details automatically</ref> Many tombs had [[fresco]] paintings, which does not seem to have been a Greek influence (though the style of the paintings are certainly based on Greek art), as the Greeks had ceased to use [[chamber tomb]]s well before the Etruscans started to paint theirs in about 600; the Egyptians had also ceased painting tombs by then.<ref>Banti, 29</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:TombaDadoBanditaccia.jpg|Tombs at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6681.jpg|Tombs at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6696.jpg|Tumulus at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6683.jpg|Maze of tumuli at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Necropoli crocifisso del tufo 2.jpg|View from above of a crowded necropolis at [[Orvieto]] File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6689.jpg|Tomb entry at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Tombadeicaronti1.jpg|Painted false door; the "hammerhead" surround is a frequent motif File:Tomba dei Leopardi Tarquinia c.jpg|[[Tomb of the Leopards]], [[Tarquinia]] </gallery>
==Walls and fortifications== [[File:Orbetello12.jpg|thumb|Wall at Orbetello]] Etruscan cities, which often sat on hill-tops, became walled from about the 8th century, first in mud-brick, then often in stone. Even before the Romans began to swallow up Etruscan territory, Italy had frequent wars, and by the later period had [[Celts|Celtic]] enemies to the north, and an expanding Rome to the south.<ref>Boethius, 33–34</ref> There was an [[Agger (ancient Rome)|agger]] or rampart and a ''fossa'' or ditch in front of the wall. The towns had a number of gates where roads entered, which were sometimes given arched gateways. The best survivor of these is the 2nd-century Porta Marzia at [[Perugia]] (illustrated above) from the end of the period. Here, as in many cases, surviving work comes from the period just around the Roman takeover, but appears to represent Etruscan traditions. By the 4th century, [[Volterra]] had two walls, the second enclosing the whole city.<ref>Christofani; Boethius, 66–68</ref>
The stonework is often of fine quality, sometimes using regular rectangular blocks in a rough [[ashlar]], and sometimes "cyclopeian", using large polygonal blocks, partly shaped to fit each other, somewhat in the manner of the well-known [[Inca architecture|Inca masonry]], though not reaching that level of quality. Gaps are left, which are filled in with much smaller stones.<ref>Boëthius et al, 67–68</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Mura etrusche di fiesole 04 blocchi ciclopici.JPG|[[Fiesole]], town wall. Fairly regular blocks in courses File:Polygonal masonry wall of Rusellae.JPG|Polygonal masonry wall at [[Rusellae]] </gallery>
==Road network== [[File:Una via cava.JPG|thumb|240px|Sunken road or [[via cava]]]] Several important and unimportant [[Roman road]]s, such as the [[Via Cassia]], overlie Etruscan precursors, but there are sufficient Etruscan sites that were neglected after their conquest to allow an understanding of the considerable Etruscan road system. Roads did not just run between cities, but out into the countryside to allow agricultural produce to be easily brought in.<ref>Izzet, 193–195</ref> While not as heavily engineered as Roman roads, considerable efforts went into creating a road surface that on major routes could be as wide as 10.4 metres, on a 12 kilometre stretch connecting [[Cerveteri]] with its port [[Pyrgi]], made in the 5th century. This had a gravel surface, between tufo edging-blocks, and a central drainage channel.<ref>Izzet, 193</ref>
The [[Vie Cave]], narrow cuttings often running deeply through hills, are probably little changed since Etruscan times. As well as connecting sites, these may have had a defensive function in times of war. Their construction may have mainly resulted from the wearing through soft tufo bedrock by iron-rimmed wheels, creating deep ruts that required the road to be frequently recut to a smooth surface. Their dating can only be deduced by that of settlements they pass between, and objects from tombs beside them.<ref>Izzet, 193</ref> The 7th and 6th centuries show a move to replace earlier tracks only suitable for mules and pedestrians with wider and more engineered roads capable of taking wheeled vehicles, using gentler but longer routes through hilly country.<ref>Izzet, 194</ref>
Bridges were common, though fords more so where these would suffice. Presumably many were in timber, but some at least used stone underneath a timber roadway.<ref>Izzet, 195</ref>

'''FedEx furniture''' is the artistic creation of computer programmer and [[creative consumer]] Jose Avila, III. In June, 2005, Avila created a website, Fedexfurniture.com, to display photographs of a couch, bed, dining room table, and desk that he had constructed out of cartons obtained from overnight shipping giant [[FedEx Corporation]] (FedEx). FedEx attorneys used the [[Notice and take down|takedown]] provisions of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) to force Avila's [[Internet service provider|ISP]] to take the site offline, accusing Avila of infringing on FedEx's [[copyright]]s and [[trademark]]s, breaching his [[contract]] with FedEx by using the cartons for purposes other than shipping, and potentially misleading consumers into believing that FedEx approved or endorsed Avila's actions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre R.|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland F.|last3=McCarthy|first3=Ian|last4=Kates|first4=Steven M.|date=2007-01-01|title=When customers get clever: Managerial approaches to dealing with creative consumers|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681306000796|journal=Business Horizons|volume=50|issue=1|pages=39–47|doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2006.05.005}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland|last3=Kietzmann|first3=Jan|last4=McCarthy|first4=Ian P.|date=2015-08-01|title=CGIP: Managing Consumer-Generated Intellectual Property|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43|journal=California Management Review|language=en|volume=57|issue=4|pages=43–62|doi=10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43|issn=0008-1256}}</ref> Among attorneys and activist organizations concerned with the exercise of [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights on the [[Internet]], FedEx's actions raised questions about the [[constitutionality]] of using the DMCA to [[censorship|censor]] unwanted speech. The Fedexfurniture.com website is down as of July 8th, 2017.
==The story==
In 2005, Avila moved to Tempe, Arizona with nothing more than clothes and work essentials. He was still stuck in a lease on his California apartment, and could barely afford his new apartment in Arizona.
After a bit of frustration over not having furniture, Avila remembered that a former roommate had solved a similar problem by constructing furniture using FedEx cartons. Using hundreds of FedEx boxes and materials that he "already had lying around" for shipping various items, Avila constructed every piece of furniture in his apartment. Avila's designs were sturdy and attractive. Friends urged Avila to put pictures of the furniture on a Web site.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland|last3=Kietzmann|first3=Jan|last4=McCarthy|first4=Ian P.|date=2015-08-01|title=CGIP: Managing Consumer-Generated Intellectual Property|url=https://doi.org/10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43|journal=California Management Review|language=en|volume=57|issue=4|pages=43–62|doi=10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre R.|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland F.|last3=McCarthy|first3=Ian|last4=Kates|first4=Steven M.|date=2007-01-01|title=When customers get clever: Managerial approaches to dealing with creative consumers|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681306000796|journal=Business Horizons|volume=50|issue=1|pages=39–47|doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2006.05.005}}</ref> According to Avila, he did so in order to show that trying financial circumstances need not lead to despair; one can respond creatively, even artistically, by using "found" materials.{{ref|ffstory}} The site's message was "It's OK to be ghetto".{{ref|counterthink}}
The site subsequently attracted widespread attention, both from Web surfers and the press. Because the site was getting so much traffic, Avila placed a PayPal donation link on the page and asked for help to pay for the bandwidth charges. He also announced a plan to sell Fedexfurniture.com T-shirts, although Avila says that no T-shirts were ever sold.{{ref|ffstory}}
On June 27, 2005, FedEx attorneys wrote to Avila's [[Internet service provider|ISP]]. Citing the takedown provisions of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA), they demanded that the ISP remove Avila's materials from the Web.{{ref|takedownnotice}} They justified their request on two grounds: *Infringement of FedEx's [[intellectual property]] (specifically, [[copyright]]s and [[trademark]]s.) *Violation of FedEx's [[terms of use]] for packaging supplies.
In order to take advantage of the [[Safe harbor (law)|safe harbor]] provisions of the DMCA, Avila's ISP complied with the request and removed Avila's materials from the Web. Had the ISP not done so, it could have been held liable for [[contributory copyright infringement|contributory infringement]] (aiding and abetting the infringer) if Avila's materials were subsequently found to be infringing in a court of law.
FedEx's actions concerned Internet free speech activist organizations, such as [[Stanford University|Stanford University's]] [[Stanford Center for Internet and Society|Center for Internet and Society]], which are concerned about the use of the DMCA's takedown provisions to [[censorship|censor]] unwanted speech. According to these organizations, the DMCA's purpose is to prevent Internet copyright infringement; it was never Congress's intent that the DMCA's takedown provisions should be used when the real issue is [[trademark infringement]] or [[breach of contract]].{{ref|fairuse}}
A Stanford attorney, [[Jennifer Granick]], assisted Avila on a [[pro bono]] basis. In her letter to FedEx, she disputed the use of the DMCA to remove Avila's site from the Web; she argued that the company's claim of [[copyright infringement]] had no merit; therefore, FedEx should not have used the DMCA to silence Avila's speech. The company's underlying motivations, she argued, were to protect its [[trademark]] and ability to place restrictions on public use of its cartons.{{ref|stanford}} Avila restored his site briefly. The dispute attracted widespread press attention, and Avila was frequently interviewed to tell his side of the story. In response to Granick's letter, FedEx attorneys reiterated their claims. Subsequently, Avila removed his site from the Web, citing technical difficulties. By January 2006, Avila's site had returned, however, by June 30, 2006 the site had again disappeared. This was caused by a server crash, and as of July 27, 2006 it was back online, but as of August 16, 2007 the site is gone. It popped up again in October 2007, but is currently down (July 8, 2017).
==See also== *[[Chilling effect (term)|Chilling effect]] *[[Conversion (law)|Conversion]] *[[Copyright]] *[[Copyright infringement]] *[[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) *[[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] *[[Free speech]] *[[Lanham Act]] *[[Online Copyright Infringement Liability Limitation Act]] *[[Trademark dilution]] *[[Trademark law]]

Also see [http://fedexaminer.com/documents/FedExLetter235.pdf FedEx to Via Internet, June 27, 2005]. #{{note|fairuse}} Marjorie Heins and Tricia Beckels (2005), [http://www.fepproject.org/policyreports/WillFairUseSurvive.pdf "Will Fair Use Survive? Free Expression in the Age of Copyright Control"]. New York, NY: Brennan Center for Justice, New York University School of Law. #{{note|stanford}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20051125030640/http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/archives/CIS%20letter.pdf Stanford Center for Internet & Society to FedEx, August 9, 2005]. #{{note|blog}} [http://pop-pr.blogspot.com/2005/08/fedex-speaks.html "FedEx Speaks!]. #{{note|mattel}}353 F.3d 792 ( 9th Circuit, 2003).
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050628000042/http://fedexfurniture.com/ fedexfurniture.com] @ web.archive.org * [http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=05/08/11/1715204&from=rss Slashdot thread about Fedexfurniture.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060426070020/http://www.counterthink.org/013109.html Corporate censorship vs. free speech]. An interesting discussion of the pros and cons of Avila's actions. * [http://pop-pr.blogspot.com/2005/08/fedex-speaks.html FedEx Speaks!] Contains a balanced look with an interview of both FedEx and an IM interview with Avila. * [https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2005/08/68492 Furniture Causes FedEx Fits] Wired News story on the site and controversy, including interviews with Avila and his lawyer.

{{refimprove|date=September 2012}} {{italic title}} '''''Fiction Weekly''''' was an [[United States|American]] [[literary magazine]] based in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]]. ''Fiction Weekly'' was conceived in the summer of 2008 by members of the [[McNeese State University]] [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA Program]] in [[creative writing]]. As its name suggests, ''Fiction Weekly'' publishes on a weekly basis; it is published exclusively on the internet and features one previously unpublished piece of [[fiction]] on its front page each week.
Authors published in ''Fiction Weekly'' have appeared in [[anthologies]] such as [[New Stories From the South]], have been nominated for the [[Pushcart Prize]], and have been published in many other well reputed literary magazines including, [[Glimmer Train]], [[The Pinch]], and [[Harpur Palate]].<ref>[http://michelle-reed.name/5.html Reed, Michelle]</ref><ref>[http://www.fictionweekly.com/theonionwasme.htm Fiction Weekly]</ref>
However, as of May 2010, the website had not been updated for six months. It was stated that the magazine ceased publication.<ref>{{cite web|title=What it was|url=http://www.fictionweekly.com/|work=Fiction Weekly|accessdate=November 1, 2015}}</ref>
==Notable Contributors== [[Michael Knight (writer)|Michael Knight]], Anya Groner, Ryan Crider, Michelle Reed, Josh Canipe, and Paul Michel.
==See also== *[[List of literary magazines]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.fictionweekly.com/ Fiction Weekly] (official website)

Last of the Enforcers | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]}} Archived July 22, 2017</ref> | country = {{plainlist| * Canada<ref name=allmovie/> * United States<ref name=allmovie/> }} | language = English | budget = | gross = [[Canadian dollar|CAD]]$1.2 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://playbackonline.ca/2017/05/02/hot-sheet-top-5-canadian-films-april-21-to-27-2017/|title=Hot Sheet: Top 5 Canadian films April 21 to 27, 2017|work=[[Playback (magazine)|Playback]]|publisher=[[Brunico Communications]]|date=May 2, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017}}</ref> }} '''''Goon: Last of the Enforcers''''' is a 2017 [[Sports film|sports]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Jay Baruchel]] in his [[List of directorial debuts|directorial debut]] and written by Baruchel and Jesse Chabot. A [[sequel]] to ''[[Goon (film)|Goon]]'' (2011), the film stars [[Seann William Scott]], Baruchel, [[Liev Schreiber]], [[Alison Pill]], [[Elisha Cuthbert]], [[Wyatt Russell]], [[Marc-André Grondin]] and [[Kim Coates]].
[[Principal photography]] began in [[Toronto]] on June 22, 2015. The film was released in Canada on March 17, 2017 and on September 1, 2017 in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=Goon: Last of the Enforcers|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movie/goon-last-of-the-enforcers-2017|website=ComingSoon.net|publisher=[[Crave Online]]|accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref>
== Plot == During a pro hockey [[Lockout (industry)|lockout]], Doug "The Thug" Glatt's ([[Seann William Scott]]) team, the Halifax Highlanders, has to contend with an influx of new players. With pro hockey suspended, media focus has descended on the lower league, and the owner of the Highlanders, Hyrum Cain ([[Callum Keith Rennie]]), seeks to capitalize on the attention. Before the opening game, Doug is made captain and leads his team out onto the ice. In a close fought game, Doug is goaded into a fight with the rival team's enforcer, Anders Cain ([[Wyatt Russell]]), an up-and-coming player with a violent streak, and the son of the Highlanders' owner. Anders wins the fight, and with Doug badly injured, the Highlanders lose the game. Dealing with rehab, Doug decides to retire and accept a more stable job as an insurance salesman. At home, Doug's wife Eva realizes that she is pregnant, and she and Doug make preparations for their new child. Without Doug, the Highlanders go on a long losing streak, prompting the owner to push for changes. He signs several overseas players and pushes to add his own son to the team. Hyrum foresees Anders as the new captain of the Highlanders, and although the coach disagrees with the move, anticipating locker room dysfunction, Hyrum strongarms him into making Anders the new captain.
Meanwhile, Doug finds no joy in his new job, stuck in a dingy office, and he begins secretly training to get back into hockey. Doug visits his old rival, Ross "The Boss" Rhea, who has left hockey and now competes in a hockey fighting league, where he is the current champion. Doug convinces Ross to train him in southpaw fighting, as the injury he suffered fighting Anders has weakened his right arm. Ross agrees to train him, and Doug slowly begins to learn how to fight left-handed. Ross convinces Doug that if he joins the hockey fighting league and impresses, it could be a way to get back into minor league hockey. Doug takes Ross' advice, but the first fight ends up being a battle royale style brawl, instead of the one-on-one fights that Doug had witnessed before. Doug and Ross end up as the last two standing during the melee, but Ross is too hurt to continue and collapses before they can fight each other. In the locker room after the fight, Ross reveals that he has [[post-concussion syndrome]], and doctors have recommended that he stop playing, as one more bad hit could cause a permanent injury.
At the same time, the Highlanders have improved with Anders as the captain, but not enough to get into playoff position. Anders' self-sabotaging play, in which he constantly is being penalized for fighting, has kept the Highlanders outside of a playoff spot. In addition, Anders' aggressive and violent attitudes towards his fellow players keeps the whole team on edge, and their play suffers as a result. During another losing effort, Anders grows frustrated and ends up knocking out the entire opposing team. He is promptly suspended, and the coach demands a change. Hyrum, having seen Doug at the hockey fighting league, suggests that they add Doug back to the roster, secretly hoping that his addition will push his son to play better. Before Doug's first game back, Eva makes Doug promise that he won't fight, concerned for him now that they're about to be parents. Doug reluctantly agrees, and the Highlanders narrowly win in Doug's celebrated return. The Highlanders go on a winning streak, but when Anders returns from suspension, he goads Doug into being more aggressive. Doug and Anders interrupt a game during a dispute, and they are both suspended for the next game. During the game's afterparty, Anders provokes Doug into a fight, and when Eva sees that Doug has been fighting again, she kicks him out of the house.
Meanwhile, the Highlanders must win the last two games of the season to sneak into the playoffs. With Anders and Doug suspended, Hyrum decides to sign Ross, who has still been competing in the local hockey fighting league. To free up a spot, Hyrum terminates Anders' contract, fed up with his son's antics. While Ross helps the Highlanders to win the first of their last two games, Eva goes into labor, and Doug reconciles with her as they head to the hospital. After having her baby, Eva realizes that the same drive that led Doug to be with her during the birth, is the same drive that pushes him to want to defend his teammates on the ice, and she gives Doug her blessing to continue fighting. Having been kicked off the team, Anders rejoins his old team, as they will play the Highlanders in the last game of the season with a playoff spot on the line. The game is immediately chippy, with both Ross and Anders starting fights. As the game enters the third period with the game tied, Ross and Anders are involved in a scuffle, and Anders cheap shots Ross, checking him from behind into the boards. Ross is knocked unconscious, and while paramedics take him away on a stretcher, Doug enters the rink to fight Anders in retaliation.
Doug uses his southpaw training to beat Anders, but when Doug shows mercy, Anders threatens Doug, claiming that he will never stop coming for him until they are both like Ross, being carried out on stretchers. Realizing that his new family is more important to him than hockey, Doug uses his weakened right arm to level Anders, but throws his arm out and has to be helped off the ice. Hyrum rushes to his son's aid, where Anders tells him that he hates hockey, and the two appear to mend things between them. Having been told earlier that further injury to his right arm would be career-ending, Doug realizes that his hockey days are behind him. He watches as the Highlanders win the game in the final seconds, and during the celebration, he sets his stick down and goes home.
== Cast == * [[Seann William Scott]] as Doug "The Thug" Glatt<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Alison Pill]] as Eva Glatt, Glatt's love interest, now married to Glatt<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Wyatt Russell]] as Anders Cain, a volatile young captain of the Halifax Highlanders<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Liev Schreiber]] as Ross "The Boss" Rhea<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Marc-André Grondin]] as Xavier LaFlamme<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Kim Coates]] as Ronnie Hortense, Highlanders coach<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Jay Baruchel]] as "Pat" Patrick Hooolihan<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Elisha Cuthbert]] as Mary, Eva's outlandish sister<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Callum Keith Rennie]], as Hyrum Cain, Highlanders owner and father of Anders<ref name="DeadlineCast" /> * [[Jonathan Cherry]] as Goalie Marco "Belchie" Belchior * Trent Pardy as Stevenson * Karl Graboshas as Oleg Yakovlena * George Tchortov as Evgeni Yakovlena * Richard Clarkin as Gord Ogilvey * [[Jason Jones (actor)|Jason Jones]] as Bob Forbes * [[T.J. Miller]]<ref name="DuthieMillerCast" /> as Chad Bailey * [[David Paetkau]] as Ira Glatt * Ellen David as Mrs. Glatt * Larry C. Woo as Park Kim * Boomer Phillips as Walters * [[James Duthie (sportscaster)|James Duthie]]<ref name="DuthieMillerCast" /> as himself
Current and former hockey players [[Tyler Seguin]], [[Michael Del Zotto]], [[Brandon Prust]], [[George Parros]], [[Colton Orr]] and [[Georges Laraque]] make appearances in the film.<ref name="SeguinZottoCast" /><ref>[http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/nhl/jay-baruchel-goon-2-last-of-the-enforcers-interview-montreal-canadiens-subban-therrien-cuthbert-tj-miller/ Q&A: Jay Baruchel talks Goon, Subban, Therrien, Elisha Cuthbert]</ref>
Doug "The Hammer" Smith, whom Doug Glatt is based on, has a cameo in the "Bruised and Battered" sequence. He is head-butted by Seann William Scott in the square-off between the two Dougs.
== Production == On September 24, 2012, it was announced that [[Jay Baruchel]] would be returning to write the sequel to ''[[Goon (film)|Goon]]'' along with Jesse Chabot, while [[Michael Dowse]] was set to return to direct the film, and [[Evan Goldberg]] to produce.<ref>{{cite news|last1=TRUMBORE|first1=DAVE|title=Jay Baruchel Tweets GOON 2 Update; Will Co-Write with Jesse Chabot and Michael Dowse Will Return to Direct; Evan Goldberg Will Produce|url=http://collider.com/jay-baruchel-goon-2-sequel/|accessdate=June 12, 2015|work=collider.com|date=September 24, 2012}}</ref> On May 15, 2015, it was announced that Baruchel would make his directorial debut on the film, titled ''Goon: Last of the Enforcers'', and would also return in the role of Pat, while [[Seann William Scott]] would also return to play the role of the hockey enforcer, Doug "The Thug" Glatt.<ref name=BaruchelScottCast>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Jay Baruchel to Direct 'Goon' Sequel (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jay-baruchel-direct-goon-sequel-795932|accessdate=June 12, 2015|work=hollywoodreporter.com|date=May 15, 2015}}</ref> Goldberg would be executive producer, while David Gross, Jesse Shapira, Jeff Arkuss and Andre Rouleau would be producers on the film.<ref name="BaruchelScottCast" /> On June 8, 2015 [[Elisha Cuthbert]] joined the cast of the film along with the returning cast of [[Liev Schreiber]] and [[Alison Pill]] from the first film.<ref name=CuthbertCast>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Elisha Cuthbert Joins Seann William Scott for 'Goon' Sequel (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/elisha-cuthbert-joins-seann-william-800949|accessdate=June 12, 2015|work=hollywoodreporter.com|date=June 8, 2015}}</ref>
On June 10, 2015, the complete cast of the film was announced by [[Entertainment One]], [[Wyatt Russell]] was set to play Anders Cain, a volatile young captain of the Halifax Highlanders, [[Marc-André Grondin]] to play a superstar Xavier LaFlamme, [[Kim Coates]] as Highlanders coach Ronnie Hortense, Pill would star as Glatt's love interest Eva and Schreiber as Ross "The Boss" Rhea, while Cuthbert would play Mary, the outlandish sister of Pill's character Eva, who is now married to Doug the Thug.<ref name=DeadlineCast>{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr|first1=Mike|title=Hockey Brawler Pic ‘Goon’ Sequel Has Wyatt Russell Squaring Off With Liev Schreiber, Seann William Scott|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/wyatt-russell-goon-sequel-liev-schreiber-seann-william-scott-1201440808/|accessdate=June 12, 2015|work=deadline.com|date=June 10, 2015}}</ref> In a tweet on July 7, 2015 from the set of the film, [[The Sports Network|TSN]]'s Sportscaster [[James Duthie (sportscaster)|James Duthie]] revealed that he and [[T.J. Miller]] were cast to play the sportscasters in the film.<ref name=DuthieMillerCast>{{cite news|title=James Duthie stars alongside T.J. Miller in the Goon sequel!|url=http://www2.tsn.ca/bardown/Story.aspx?James+Duthie+stars+alongside+T.J.+Miller+in+the+Goon+sequel!&id=549715|accessdate=July 23, 2015|work=tsn.ca|date=July 8, 2015}}</ref> On July 23, 2015, real NHL players [[Tyler Seguin]] and [[Michael Del Zotto]] were spotted on the set during filming along with Scott.<ref name=SeguinZottoCast>{{cite news|last1=Peters|first1=Chris|title=LOOK: Tyler Seguin, Michael Del Zotto on set for 'Goon 2' cameos|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nhl/eye-on-hockey/25248579/look-tyler-seguin-michael-del-zotto-on-set-for-goon-2-cameos|accessdate=July 24, 2015|work=cbssports.com|date=July 23, 2015}}</ref> On August 7, 2015, a tweet by [[Georges Laraque]] stated that he was headed to the set with [[Colton Orr]] and [[George Parros]].<ref>{{cite tweet |author= Georges Laraque |user= GeorgesLaraque |number= 629660432874229760 |date= Aug 7, 2015 |title= With Colton Orr and @GeorgeParros on our way to the set to film "Goon 2" yeah! |access-date= May 11, 2017}}</ref>
=== Filming === [[Principal photography]] on the film began on June 22, 2015, in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]].<ref name="DeadlineCast" /><ref>{{cite news|title=On the Set for 6/22/15: Spielberg’s ‘The Bfg’ Wraps Along with ‘Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles’ Sequel, Woody Harrelson Starts ‘Wilson’|url=http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-62215-spielbergs-the-bfg-wraps-along-with-teenage-mutant-ninja-turtles-sequel-woody-harrelson-starts-wilson/|accessdate=June 23, 2015|work=ssninsider.com|date=June 22, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627012735/http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-62215-spielbergs-the-bfg-wraps-along-with-teenage-mutant-ninja-turtles-sequel-woody-harrelson-starts-wilson/|archivedate=June 27, 2015|df=}}</ref> Baruchel also tweeted the photo of the cast from the set.<ref>{{cite tweet |author= Jay Baruchel |user= BaruchelNDG |number= 611993064773709824 |date= June 19, 2015 |title= The boys are back in town. #GOON #LASTOFTHEENFORCERS |access-date= May 11, 2017}}</ref> Late-June, filming was taking place in Hamilton, Ontario's Corktown<ref>{{Cite web|title = Browse by Corktown in Area at Historical Hamilton|url = http://historicalhamilton.com/corktown/|website = historicalhamilton.com|accessdate = 2015-08-29}}</ref> area, the [[Barrie Molson Centre]] in [[Barrie, Ontario|Barrie]] in July until August 13, 2015<ref>{{cite news|title=Extras wanted for 'Goons 2' filming in Barrie|url=http://barrie.ctvnews.ca/extras-wanted-for-goon-2-filming-in-barrie-1.2460243|accessdate=July 8, 2015|work=barrie.ctvnews.ca|date=July 8, 2015}}</ref> and near [[Bayfront Park (Hamilton, Ontario)|Bayfront Park]] in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Filming in Hamilton this week|url=http://www.thespec.com/whatson-story/5701185-filming-in-hamilton-this-week-/|accessdate=July 1, 2015|work=thespec.com|date=June 30, 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== On review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 44%, based on 48 reviews, with an average rating of 5/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Seann William Scott remains as watchable as ever in the title role, but ''Goon: Last of the Enforcers'' repeats its predecessor's violent and profane formula to diminishing effect."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/goon_last_of_the_enforcers/|title=Goon: Last of the Enforcers (2017)|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=September 1, 2017}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating to reviews, the film has a weighted average score of 50 out of 100, based on reviews from 16 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/goon-last-of-the-enforcers|title=Goon: Last of the Enforcers reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|website=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=September 1, 2017}}</ref>
Barry Hertz from ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' gave the film 3 out of 4 and wrote "Baruchel's sequel is everything Dowse's original film was, amped up a degree or three: The fights involving dim-bulb hero Doug (Seann William Scott) and his various rivals are bloodier, the locker-room talk is dirtier and the on-ice action is slicker. The unlikely project – how many made-in-Canada films spark a franchise? – doesn't quite reach the heights of the original film, which found surprising pathos in Doug's tale of sweet good guy to brutal goon. But it delivers on nearly every other scale, including standout performances from returning players Scott, Alison Pill and Liev Schreiber, as well as some bits of comic gold courtesy of series rookies Wyatt Russell, T.J. Miller and Jason Jones."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hertz|first1=Barry|title=Goon: Last of the Enforcers is a welcome addition to a Canadian hockey franchise|url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/film-reviews/goon-last-of-the-enforcers-is-a-welcome-addition-to-a-canadian-hockey-franchise/article34325771/|accessdate=August 12, 2017|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=March 17, 2017}}</ref> ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' gave the film 3.5 out of 5, and stated "Violent, crude and really funny, ''Goon: Last of The Enforcers'', works for the same reason the original Goon worked — you will love the characters."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Braun|first1=Liz|title='Goon: Last of the Enforcers' review: Violent, crude and funny|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2017/03/16/goon-last-of-the-enforcers-review-violent-crude-and-funny|accessdate=August 12, 2017|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> ''[[National Post]]'' gave the film a 1 out of 4.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marsh|first1=Calum|title=Gross misconduct: The unfunny Goon sequel is everything its predecessor managed not to be|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/arts/movies/gross-misconduct-the-unfunny-goon-sequel-is-everything-its-predecessor-managed-not-to-be|accessdate=May 11, 2017|work=[[National Post]]|date=March 19, 2017}}</ref>
